scenes.location: A WAITING BUS, (ON THE STUDIO LOT) ON THE STUDIO LOT
characters: THE FILM, (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM)
THE BIG ROOM IN THE RANCH-HOUSE
ANOTHER ROOM SOMEWHERE IN THE HOUSE
THE ACTRESS HERSELF, (DRIVING HER OWN CAR)
SERIES OF FLASHES, (ALL OVER THE DARKENED RANCH)
THE PROJECTION ROOM AT THE RANCH
THE VALESKA TV _ INTERVIEW, (IN THE LIBRARY)
THE ROW OF DUMMIES ON THE ROCKS
THE DESERT ROAD AND DRIVEWAY LEADING UP TO THE RANCH
THE FRONT OF THE RANCH HOUSE
FFF FFF FF FFL E ETH H4
THE BLONDE, (IN A TIGHT GROUP SHOT)
THE PARKING SPACE IN FRONT OF THE RANCH

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (to Julie Rich) ++. Over budget? A picture's a success -- who remembers what it cost?  14

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (climbing into the bus) Zimmer... I got to give you a message.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (after a beat) From Jake? I got that message. Everybody heard.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Not this message. Pause... Not a move, not a blink from MATT.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: I’m fired. That’s the message. MATT’S continued immobility supplies the answer

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: JULIE RICH and her own camera and sound men. Also a couple of lesser fish in the world of European journalism. ZIMMER (contd. ) So what am I doing going to his party?  15

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You're invited.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: ... With all these stupid dummies -- !

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're invited.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Jokes...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You know how he is sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: I know how he’s getting... JULIE RICH pricks up her ears at this, and signals to her cameraman. MATT catches her at it.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The bus rolling on along the freeway... Aboard there is yet another DOCUMENTARY CAMERA CREW, but most of the passengers are ZIMMER’S SUPERNUMERARY DUMMIES. One of these last is propped up in a seat beside ZIMMER himself. Matt, PAT and MAGGIE are nearby... AL is with MISS RICH.  16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A much livelier scene including the midgets and the girls (the nudes from the steambath)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So here you are in Hollywood, Julie... I bet life was never like this in -- what was that little hick town you were born in -- ? Dijon, France --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (very cool) Oh...?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just remembered. You aren’t French, though -- you’re Polak extraction.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (coldly) You seem to know quite a lot about me, Mr. Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (giving her the old smile) Call me Matt.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (in a tone of weary bitterness) Old Matt -- he knows just about everybody. He’s on that Committee --  17

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Pipe down, Zimmie.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: The one that decides if you’re American.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: I’m not American...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Maybe you didn’t know these people are still in business.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (a whiff of quiet menace ) We’re in business, Zimmie.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford’s investigated me?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Well, not Jake exactly...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (the phone to his ear) No -- he isn’t on our Committee -- The bus starts with a jerk, shaking everybody --

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: We gotta be a little careful, don’t we?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to Mlle. RICH) That’s all right, Julie... You don’t have to worry. You're clean.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: --. No editing, really -- just the slates cut off...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: So what am I going to see -- everything he’s shot up to now?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The first couple reels, Max. The rest’s already out at the ranch... Zarah’s giving him this party, and she invited all these movie freaks... Bleak, blank silence from MAX DAVID. He waits again for some sort of reaction, and once again gets nothing. We'll see the rest of us the stuff when we get there...  19 BILLY (cont) (contd. ) Zarah’s expecting you, Max... So is Jake --

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: I was expecting him here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jammed into the back are the two cinema historians And biographers, HIGGAM and PISTER, also a DOCUMENTARY CREW (sound and camera)... They can see J.J. HANNAFORD in the driver’s mirror; he’s wearing sunglasses... Sitting beside him is his comrade and disciple, the highl successful young film director BROOKS OTTERLAKE. (OTTER- LAKE is also a talented and compulsive impressionist. With JAKE particularly -- with whom he is now, secretly, more than a bit uneasy -- he tends to jump from one “Voic to another.) Another CAMERAMAN IS SQUEEZED next to him. In the back seat: A flurry of hushed haggling between HIGGAM and PISTER, an a perfect frenzy of interviews... PISTER wants to know, among other things, if MR. HANNAFORD considers that “the camera is a phallus?” Maybe JAKE doesn’t hear...  20

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Brooksie --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Right here at your side, Skipper.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Know what I want for my birthday?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (indicating the cineastes in the back) Not this, I bet --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I want a drink.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOUND MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford... Do you mind driving a little slower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprawled dangerously on the back of the car, clutching his microphone. THE SOUND MAN (contd. ) I’m afraid I'll fall off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIE’S VOICE (0.S.) Aw, come on, Zimmie. Jake’s fine. He’s just like he always was.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (I’m a make-up man)... an expert. All my life I’ve been sticking my nose into other people’s wrinkles. I know the little signs. (after a beat) It's something you could almost... smell. That’s what the gypsies say.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (dismissing foolishness) Gypsies...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Nine months we practically lived with them... Jake’s first picture in Spain. A flamenco guitar is strumming... but gloom hangs heavy over the group of HANNAFORD executives seated among the dummies...

dialogues.speaker: A_ MOVIE SCREEN...
dialogues.text: The lights go out... THE FILM begins... 22

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (to JULIE RICH) “Matador” -- remember that one?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: The new one’s what I care about --

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: “The Other Side Of The Wind”... (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, sitting beside MAX DAVID, is doing his best to act as interpreter, salesman and apologist.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: This is toward to the beginning... It comes right after what we were shooting today... She leaves the steamroom, and here’s this character waiting for her...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: Dale something?  23

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: John Dale, Max... He’s the kid on the motorcycle. The one in the middle... Silence... THE FILM continues... then CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (defensively) Aw, he’s picked ‘em before...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Nobody knows that better than Zimmie... Nobody’s been with him any longer.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Well, I was never a member of the old wolf-pack. If you’re Jewish, to get into that club, you gotta be charming...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You’re charming enough, Zimmie -- (turning back in his seat)  ZIMMER sighs... She reacts to this. 24 MATT (contd. ) You’re just sore about the dummies.

dialogues.speaker: AL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know how he feels. Zimmie put in a lot of good work for him...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: The bridge for Randy Leigh's nose. I created that nose: the famous profile -- it made him a star.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Jake made him a star...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t need to make stars -- just movies. MAGGIE (contd.) You don’t think so?

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (looking at the dummy) I don’t know what I think of this one --

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Who does?  CU: THE DUMMY HEAD...

dialogues.speaker: THE FILM, (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM)
dialogues.text: (shots featuring JOHN DALE)... BILLY can’t think of an answer to this.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (after watching in silence for a while) He looks like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: They do nowadays, that’s how they want to look -- It’s the scene, Max...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: Which scene?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The scene...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (sarcastic, but not pressing hard) Oh?... And you old guys | are trying to... ‘get with it’ -- ? Is that what this movie’s about? (then after a beat)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S CAR
dialogues.text: He switches on the playback of his 26 MAX DAVID (contd. ) No?... Well, just what is it about?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’‘ll try to explain, Max -- as we go along...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to HIGGAM and

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: All right, men -- let’s get organized... Where shall we start -- where old Dad here ran away to sea? Or way back to the ancestors? (change of voice-- as a cinema freak) They were all actors, weren’t they, Mr. Hannaford? (change of voice) Worse than that -- they were Irishmen. (his own voice) Here’s the original -- not that it’s as good... miniature tape recorder.  A whirring sound and the tape recorder falls silent... During this last he changes cartridges in his tape recorder. 27

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (playback) Most of the old actor-managers were micks. Barret, McCullough, Hannaford, O’Neil... What else was there to be? You carried bricks, got into politics or went on the stage. Old Junius Hannaford was pretty big in High Tragedy before the Civil War. And Junius Junior as befits the second generation, made it into High Society -- a pioneer snob blazing the trail for the Kellys and the Kennedys...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: That’s a run-out; but I know the rest. Mr. Hannaford’s father went into the movies --

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM
dialogues.text: “Mayfair Max -- “”

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “Gentleman Jewel Thief” -- right! Y’see, Skipper -- everybody knows everything. He made three of those pictures...  28 He turns on the playback. OTTERLAKE has flicked off the little sound machine... JAKE glances at him sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: THE STUDIO PROJECITON
dialogues.text: THE FILM continues...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (on playback) .-.. And everybody was happy till they found him one Sunday morning in his suite in the old Hollywood Hotel hanging from the chadel -- Censorship?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (doesn’t reply to the question, but returns, a bit defensively, to his former breezy style) After that you had to go to work for a living -- (to those in the back seat) Give the Skipper his hooch, will you --

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: A brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: According to Jake, the box likes him...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (an indifferent mumble) Box?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The old magic box. If the camera doesn’t like an actor, it just stares... (another beat) That’s what Jake says.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: And if the actor doesn’t like the old magic director?...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: And the girl? (then, after a beat) How does the box feel about her?

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS HERSELF, (DRIVING HER OWN CAR)
dialogues.text: Like everyone else, on her way to the birthday party...  30 contd... She comes to a stop next to JAKE'S car: they’re both waiting for a traffic light.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (aside to JERRY) Pocohontas... (A bit of rather stoogish laughter greets this from the back seat) OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Zarah was gonna invite your man, too... We put a stop to that, I reckon --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (blankly) Nobody can find him. OTTERLAKE turns to look at him... the lights change, JAKE guns the car and it leaps forward (leaving THE ACTRESS behind)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: HANNAFORD’S MOVIE (IN THE STUDIO PROJECTION ROOM) THE ACTRESS featured in a scene now showing on the screen...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: She’s an Indian? -- a red Indian?  31

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (with a mirthless chuckle) A red, red Indian -- (then rather quickly) In the story... You'll meet her out at the party, Max.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: And the boy -- BILLY can think of nothing useful to say to this...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s true what Silence... HANNAFORD’S_ MOVIE Continues...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S CAR
dialogues.text: Coming out of a tunnel...

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: ” (contd. ) I hear? (his mike fully erect) Perhaps you’d care to assess the trauma of your father’s suicide as it may have been reflected in your films?  32 PISTER (contd. ) (getting ready to repeat his question) Mr. Hannaford --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (briskly changing voices -- some celebrated and ridiculously inap- propriate character) Mr. Hannaford began his career as a prop an in the old cliff-hangers... Bombs, buzz-saws, pits full of deadly serpents -- he provided all the disasters --

dialogues.speaker: PISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mumbles...

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?... Of course, it was Hollywood --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (half to himself) Another town of the same name...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (after a brief pause, prompting him) Yeah -- ?  Another tiny pause.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A cross between a small-time mud-show and a mining camp... Exhilarating.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (prompting again) You shared a bungalow with your first leading man -- I even know his name: Frank Fryer. How about that? And I’m the only one that’s not doing a book on you --

dialogues.speaker: PISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You aren’t drinking either.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: I thought you were, Otterlake --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: The whiskey’s for him, Pister, and let’s have it -- ! ...The book, you mean -- ? My book on Hannaford is how I got to Hollywood -- The publishers’ advance... Lots of very busy business in the back seat as JAKE’s drink is prepared and passed up to him...  34 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Five chapters took the two of us two and a half years... I finally had to begin directing movies myself so I could eat.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The rest is history.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And now you’re too busy?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: No, but he is -- And take it from me, fellas, he hates being interviewed. That’s what’s making this whole thing today so delightful... Zarah’s idea --

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM
dialogues.text: (unnecessarily) Zarah Valeska.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (assuming another famous voice) She is the one giving the party -- (another voice) Yes, and she’s the one dreamed up this crazy communications orgy, where ‘the younger people of the cinema’ -- (in his own voice) -- whatever that means, are let loose on him. Well, happy birthday...  35 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) I donated a lot of my old tapes -- (into yet another impression) Scattered ‘em here and there among you cineastes, just out of kindness. We can spare him a few questions, I figure, if the answers come first. The cineastes in the back seat are too confused by this virtuosity to really take it in. OTTERLAKE (contd. ) Answers are my department... The first Hannaford films? -- Silents, with David Fryer. Action pictures -- (another voice) Plenty of action. Why, Jake and Dave used to strip to the waist every Saturday night, put their two pay envelopes on the mantlepiece and fight each other for the pot... (then, after a moment, in his own voice) Whatever happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Fryers? I don’t know, kid.  36

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: They come and they go.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: They sure n’hell go.

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM
dialogues.text: John Dale, for instance? (HIGGAM is trying to push his way into an exclusive club, but not making it, of course.) TIGHT TWO SHOT: JAKE and

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: JAKE says nothing... goes on driving. HIGGAM’S VOICE (0.S.) (he doesn’t know when to stop) The latest of all those actors you’ve discovered...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a moment, to OTTERLAKE rather than HIGGAM -- almost to himself) Discovered?... Like you went pearling for ‘em and squeezed your movie star out of an oyster...  37 A title is flashed on the screen. “SCENE MISSING” The screen is in --

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: Just how much is missing?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not too much, really -- To BILLY’S relief the title is now replaced on the screen by -- HANNAFORD’S FILM...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What happens here? BILLY’S VOICE (unhappily) I’m not really sure, Max. Maybe it’s here she leaves the bomb...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What’s the bomb for? BILLY’S VOICE (with a short nervous laugh) Jesus, I don’t know...  38 Another title: “SCENE MISSING” BILLY'S VOICE (contd. ) Maybe he’s changing his mind, and there won’t be any...

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: A rough looking character roars past JAKE’S car on a motorcycle, then slows, signalling...

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUGH CHARACTER
dialogues.text: That cop back there -- he’s waving at ya...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Wave back Brooksie.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUGH CHARACTER
dialogues.text: You guys are overloaded --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUGH CHARACTER
dialogues.text: Somebody’1l have to go --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Can he go with you, Jack?  39

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUGH CHARACTER
dialogues.text: I don’t have the insurance... See ya at the party -- He roars away up the road...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Do I have the pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: He knows you, all right --

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: (the one in front) Pretty good director --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: He thinks he is you. (then, with a quick grin) But don’t we all? Meanwhile, PISTER is about to be tossed out on his ear. It seems that the law won’t allow the SOUNDMAN to ride on the trunk of the car, so room has to be made for him on a seat. As things work out, it’s not HIGGAM but PISTER who is ejected, tape recorded and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (speaking the name with distaste) Simon. Jack Simon

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (starting the car) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: A brand new bottling work has been opened at Mac Factor’s just to keep the boy supplied with blood. As the car drives away, PISTER is left with his tape recorder all forlorn on the roadside.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: If he didn’t just walk off the set -- if he quit the picture -- How’1l you finish it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He’1l come back...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: What if he doesn’t?  41

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well... Jake’s got a whole lot of ideas --

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (struggling to find something to say) There isn’t too much I can tell you, Max. You know how much of the picture he just carried in his head... HANNAFORD’S FILM continues... Then --

dialogues.speaker: A_ MONSTER AIRPLANE
dialogues.text: it screams by overhead... We are in:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S CAR
dialogues.text: An hysterical little episode in which another car in the birthday party procession catches up with

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S. A SEXY GIRL INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: is forcibly added to his passenger list and now it’s HIGGAM who is ejected, tape recorder and all.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (irritably) -.--So what are the toys about?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (increasingly on the defensive) Well... before this, she’1l be pretending to look in the window at ‘em -- That is, when we get around to shooting it -- But really she was just making sure nobody’s following her.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: The boy’s been following her -- she’s got to know that.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (starting to drown slightly) Others, beside him... like the FBI or something.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: She’s some kind of crook?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Some kinda radical, Max (interrupting himself speaking quickly)  43 BILLY (contd. ) Anyway, there’s some shops there, and the boy thinks she’s been looking at this doll...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (flatly) Which doll -- ?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (after a short silence) The one he thinks she was looking at. So... he goes in and buys it for her... (he offers this last as though it explained

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: everything) MAX DAVID sighs quietly, but makes no comment.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS
dialogues.text: It stops as PISTER signals to it... He climbs aboard.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to PISTER) Having fun, Mr. Pister?

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: The people in that last car were kind of awful.  44

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford’s car?

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: They threw me out. And then I was picked up by a lot of video-freaks -- But they ran out of gas, or needed to fix something... As he takes a seat in what might be called the executive section, the bus starts up again...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (well along with his drinking) Hippies... (he pats the top of the dummy’s head) That’s what junior here is all about.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (looking closely at the dummy ) John Dale...?

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (to MATT) The hair... that doesn’t make him a hippie. Kids today --

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Yeah?... What do you know about it?  45

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: What does Jake know -- at his age?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He’d better know.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: I’ve got some material on that... PISTER fiddles with his tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (dropping his voice) The way I heard it, he’s putting up his own money --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (cutting him off with the answer) The banks wanted a name.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (indicating the dummy) And Jake wanted him... They all stare at the dummy . A baby.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The world’s full of ‘em, Zimmie, or haven't you noticed?

dialogues.speaker: THE STUDIO PROJECITON ROOM
dialogues.text: HANNAFORD‘S FILM continues on the screen... MAX DAVID finally breaks the silence:

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (a hint of weariness) What’s in the package? BILLY clears his throat nervously.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The package... Y’mean what she’s got in her bag?

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s either a bomb on her lunch -- huh?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The kid’s package -- (quick change of tone) You saw it already, that’s the doll.. Once again the title appears on the screen:

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (carefully patient) Just tell me this, Jimmy --  47

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Billy --

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: There going to be film where it shows there’s a doll in this package?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s easy, Max -- just an insert...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: And the bomb?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, Max?

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: If it was left in the building, when does it blow up?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The bomb is... Well, we don’t actually know...

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: (cutting in) What do we know?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (at the end of his tether) Better ask Jake.

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: I'd better read a script. (another brief silence) You haven’t got one? -- (this next is not a question) Jake is just making it up as he goes along.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (weakly) He’s done it before...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Look what he did with the other: Glen Garvey... Courtney Saxon --

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Courtney? He was selling vacuum cleaners when Jake discovered him.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (disregarding this last) And as for Hannaford himself --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (quickly) What about him?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Branch Sutter -- he was a dish- washer...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (staring at the dummy) Could be that he’s wrong this time...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Who says so?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (turning to look out the window) Zimmer. He’s got this sensitive nose.

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: That’s all right, Maggie; never mind the smell -- Everything stinks a little.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’re telling mother.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «+. When I’m done with an actor -- I’m done. He’s as dead as cold mutton...  50

dialogues.speaker: C.U. THE ACTRESS, (DRIVING HER CAR)
dialogues.text: LUCAS listening to the playback on his tape recorder...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It’s like the end of a love affair -- All you want is out... JAKE is speaking to his young friend OTTERLAKE but this is being photographed and recorded in triplicate.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s what he got.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: For the director, you know -- it’s a kind of...phony honeymoon. You're the groom: You gotta make a fair job of romancing the poor cows.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS
dialogues.text: Suddenly PISTER’S tape recorder comes shrilly (HAND WRITTEN NOTE: to life: “INCOMPLETE” ] MATT’S VOICE (playback) Speak for yourself, Skippper --  MATT laughs in 51

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (on camera) That’s you Matt --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We know ‘em, uncle -- we have to...

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: That’s Mr. Hannaford --

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: Shhh -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We gotta know about everybody -- The creeps and freaks aren’t as much fun as the real gypsies, but something sets our teeth on edge, we do the chic and manly thing, Matthew -- We don’t sulk and turn away. No. We bend over and take a good hard sniff. MATT’S VOICE You don’t have to bend over to smell a hippie. He’s like a polecat; he meets you more than half way. appreciation of his own recorded remark.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (on camera) Like the gypsies, huh, Zimmie?  52

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: Gypsies?... PISTER is searching in his files, looking up ‘G’ for ‘gypsy’...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's what the gypsies can smell -- right, Zimmie? ["YES"]

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: (an irritated mumble) Death... anybody could smell it...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Aw, put a can on it --

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: He’s turning sour, Matt... He’s going bad. LUCAS’ VOICE «+. Dream projections of Hannaford himself?

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS, (IN HERICAR)
dialogues.text: Driving very fast, concentrating on the job. TRUMAN LOCKWOOD is sitting  53

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS, (IN HER CAR)
dialogues.text: Beside her with his camera. In the back are CICCIO TUCCI, a cameraman from Rome, and LUCAS RENARD.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: Man, they’re real -- He made ‘em real; gave ‘em existence -- he moulded the clay --

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: Or cut ‘em out with a pair of scissors.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: He conceived ‘em... Like a god.

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS
dialogues.text: (under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: -- a terrible and jealous god... That's just what he’s been for this new boy of his. John Dale is Hannaford’s personal creation -- (lowering his voice) There’s something else, too... an even stronger claim... (with a smile) Very much in the Hannaford style...  54

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS
dialogues.text: PISTER has been searching in his files, looking up ‘G’ for ‘gypsy’...

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (bringing forth a sheet of paper) Here we are -- ‘Gypsies’ -- Transcribed from my own tapes. I was there when he said it... (handing the paper to Pat) Here...

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Gypsies -- Hitler got rid of them, too. But he could have fumigated the whole world, and there’d still be the other ones -- the hippies and beatniks -- the bums... Call ‘em what you want to, they slack and slouch around on the floor because they like it down there. Talk about the return to the womb? What about the return to the cave? Junk... Junk is how you get there... That's how you dig your way back... Junk for the cool dreams, kid; and the cool, dim, anonymous gang-bang... the mutual jack-off’... (he laughs)  55 PAT (contd.) That’s sure tellin’ it like it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now PAT’S VOICE is replaced by JAKE'S issuing tinnily from the speaker of a tape recorder:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: «+. Randy Moore, for instance: he was a prop-boy... David Leigh was an extra: Neil Trevor, Branch Sutter... We see:

dialogues.speaker: A NEW TAPE RECORDER --
dialogues.text: Then a wider angle shows us:

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS IN HER CAR
dialogues.text: (Where LUCAS is playing this tape)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I happened to notice ‘em... But Dale I found. Literally. Fished him out of the sea. Now that’s what you’d call a discovery... Dale was flapping around like something you bring up in a net... BILLY’S VOICE (playback) You should have thrown him back. He was too small.  56

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (quickly to the others) Just listen...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (playback) You had to go and make him an actor --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We did what we could. Kept him on the yacht; signed him on as a deck- hand, made a sailor out of him. Or tried to... Sure I rescued him. (grimly; after a moment ) I’ve been rescuing him ever since. C.U. LUCAS as he turns off the playback.

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: You get it? He saved the cat’s life.

dialogues.speaker: TRUMAN
dialogues.text: (turning to THE ACTRESS -- half questioning) So John Dale’s in debt to the old man for that...?

dialogues.speaker: LUCAS
dialogues.text: (earnestly) Can you imagine a relationship more all-consuming? -- between master and slave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 She goes on driving and makes no comment.

dialogues.speaker: THE STUDIO PROJECITON ROOM
dialogues.text: Heavy silence from MAX DAVID as HANNAFORD'S FILM conitnues on the screen... A FLASH OF BILLY’S

dialogues.speaker: ANGUISHED FACE
dialogues.text: Silence...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (plaintively) Understand, Max -- This isn’t even a rough-cut... (beginning to betray a certain desperation) You’re going to have to see the entire movie --

dialogues.speaker: MAX DAVID
dialogues.text: Sure. And Jake’s going to have to shoot it --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Like I told you, Max, an awful lot of the footage is out at the ranch. We'll be screening it for you at the party.  58 [“DON'T HAVE” ] MAX DAVID sits, sphinx-like staring at the empty screen...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER BLANK MOVIE SCREEN
dialogues.text: This is at the HANNAFORD RANCH (in a room used for film projection)... No theatre-type seats here, just a mixture of chairs and couches. These are occupied now by a variety of guests... To celebrate J.J. HANNAFORD’S birthday, ZARAH VALESKA has invited the widest possible range of cineastes and cinema buffs. She has managed to include such men as CHARBOL, GODARD, RHOMER, TRUFFAUT and BURTOLUCCI, as well as some of the brighter young Spaniards and Englishmen. And of course, there are premier figures from the younger Americans: JACK NICHOLSON, DENNIS HOPPER, CASSAVETES, NAZURSKY, HENRY JAGLOM -- the whole spectrum, from video-freaks to ANDY WARHOL. By no means all of these are already here in this pro- jection room. Many are scattered about the ranch, arguing together or just quietly getting stoned. It’s still early...

dialogues.speaker: A GUEST
dialogues.text: (one of the celebrities) Hey, that’s the Baron -- Ask him...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER GUEST
dialogues.text: (to THE BARON, who has just looked in at the door) We'd like to see the movie --  59

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (politely) We've got all night for it... g g. ["DON'T HAVE” ] (as he turns to go) Lots of people haven’t arrived --

dialogues.speaker: THE DESERT ROAD AND DRIVEWAY LEADING UP TO THE RANCH
dialogues.text: [“YES" ] Night is falling fast as cars and buses jam into the driveway. Guests of every description are piling out and climbing the picturesque stairway leading up through the great rocks to the ranch-house above... They are pursued (as is just about everyone this evening) by zoom lenses and “sun guns.” SERIES OF SHOTS: (EXTERIOR AND INTERIOR) [“NO” ] In_ conversations such as the following, the actual speakers are only occasionally to be found directly on camera. The voices, for much of the time, Functioning as a sort of informal chorus. OSSAWATOMIE DULUTH: (we are picking this up in the middle of another argument): ++. we’re not inny of us gonna lose inny sleep ovah Hannaford... (NOTE: This is an approximation of OSSIE'S accent. It is given here merely as_a_ sample and will not be repeated. DELLA: Look -- I’ve known everybody -- OSSIE: I don’t deny him one single white hair on his chest, lovely -- DELLA: And nobody's in his league --  60 OSSIE: But as a film-maker -- KLEE: For us, Jake is Scotch whiskey, and red steaks -- TRUMAN: Well, I wouldn’t put Hannaford with people like Renoir or Eisenstein. Sorry -- Einstein.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRWAY BETWEEN THE ROCKS
dialogues.text: In the arms of grips, bus-boys, ZIMMER’S whole collection of dummies, emerging from the bus, proceeds grotesquely upwards... Besides the arrival of students, scholars and other cinema celebrities, the different cameras are recording a mixed bag of “Beautiful People” (among whom OSSIE is a popular figure). These people don’t count for much among the film-makers, but they’re here -- along with the midgets, the nudes from HANNAFORD’S movie, and a surly tribe of video-freaks). (These conversations are merely accompaniment: ) SUZIE: Quite a spread... TRAVIS: The late and next to last Mrs. Hannaford, of course, was loaded. TONY: You should see the farm out in Kenya -- LIZA: Oh, that’s gone now -- And the yacht... One of the numberless cameras recording all of this browses for a moment over the fierce shapes of big game heads decorating some of the walls.  61

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (looking up at a tiger's head) We got that one the hard way --

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: The hard way -- ? Standing up ina hammock? (change of tone) Where’s the High Priestess?

dialogues.speaker: DELLA
dialogues.text: Zarah Valeska? Actually, Fiona’s doing her... in black and white.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: Priestess of what -- ?

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: The Clan, honey -- (with heavy sarcasm) The wild and woolly old Hannaford wolf-pack -- (to DELLA) Black and white?  62

dialogues.speaker: DELLA
dialogues.text: Well, it’s her period...

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: It's certainly his --

dialogues.speaker: DELLA
dialogues.text: Fiona’s even got old Otto what’s- his-name on the camera.

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Sounds campy to me.

dialogues.speaker: DELLA
dialogues.text: Campy? That early Hannaford style is --

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: (over-lap) Von Stroheim --

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) Yes, you’re thinking of Von Stroheim.  63

dialogues.speaker: CHARBOL
dialogues.text: Von Sternberg...

dialogues.speaker: THE SLATE BOY
dialogues.text: Zarah Valeska -- Take Two! He exits with his slate. We are confronted with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OTTO, (a nice, tired old cameraman) has triumphantly Managed the correct, classic arrangement of lights... A pause, We are in:

dialogues.speaker: THE LIBRARY IN THE RANCH
dialogues.text: With cool, professional patience, ZARAH is submitting herself to a filmed inter- view conducted by the metallic FIONA DE LALLY (of day-time T.V. Fame), whose voice, after a short, tense silence, comes brightly from behind the lights:

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Zarah, you name has been linked romantically with quite a few celebrities... Her voice trails away into silence.  64

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (pained but still polite) Wasn’t it understood that we were going to talk about love affairs?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (to the camera crew) Cut!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cut!

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (quietly pained) What you agreed to talk about is Mister Hannaford -- The cameras have stopped (but not that of the DOCUMENTARY MAKER who is covering this froma semi-hiding place) ZARAH'S patience remains monumental. ZARAH (contd. ) (a helpful suggestion) I can tell you a story...

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: All right, darling... if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: THE SLATE BOY
dialogues.text: Zarah Valeska -- take Four!  65

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (starting her anecdote) One night...

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (a hurried whisper) Call me “Fiona” while you’re on camera, darling: it’s so much warmer... Go on...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: This is many years ago in Paris -- a big, open Bugatti turned and stopped directly in front of me --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (prompting unneces-— sarily, with a dry toothed smile of professional interest) -- And this was Jake, of course?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (coolly, patiently helpful) It's how we first met, you understand -- in the street. He just thought he was picking up a whore --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Ouch...! Wait a minute --  66

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (in her wide-eyed way) Whores are out?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (sweetly chiding) It’s a woman’s program, dear.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: It's a woman’s profession. VOICES are heard calling from various parts of the ranch: “He's coming -- !” “It’s Hannaford -- “Here he is -- !"

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do we cut?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (quietly raging) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cut!  67 Pandemonium! A crush of cameras and cineastes...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF QUICK FLASHES
dialogues.text: (like most of our incidental scenes, this plays quickly but takes much longer to describe.) At first we catch only glimpses of JAKE, ringed by blinding circles of sun-guns and flash-bulbs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the friendlier cineastes, flushed with drink and indignation, is arguing with some of HANNAFORD'S attackers:

dialogues.speaker: THE CINEASTE
dialogues.text: -- a fascist, for Chrissake? Jake --?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: You got the wrong man, fellas; how about Jack Simon here?

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: You tell us, Brooksie.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to the others) It’s in his contract -- Every picture he directs, he gets to shoot all the animals, personally. With a gun, that is. They even pay him off in guns --  68

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: They pay me money, kid.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (fixing SIMON with a hard smile) And they say I imitate him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: (with a quiet menace ) That’s your thing, Otterlake. real good at imitations...

dialogues.speaker: A BLONDE
dialogues.text: (called MAVIS) Do Jack Benny --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE is changing a big empty glass for a very full one. His eyes are on THE ACTRESS. (She pays no attention to him)... ABE VOGEL. The distin- guished Hollywood agent, makes his way through the milling crowds to JAKE'S side.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Hi there, Jake -- Happy birthday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE, entering the scene, cheerfully sabotages his own defense: 69

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CINEASTE
dialogues.text: Shall we define our terms?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Shall we not.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Spades, spics, micks, hunkies, honkies and hebes -- There’s a few terms for ya... (burlesque red- neck) A fassatist now -- he don’t like them people --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (behind JAKE) And what kind of people do you like?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (with a benign all- embracing smile) Nobody. (turning to VOGEL) Abie -- ! How nice to see you looking so old.  70

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (to JULIE, dip- lomatically) Nobody in the plural...

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Then who in the particular? JAKE turns to her with that maddeningly blank look of his -- (like the proud parent of a hope- less brat)... Silence... then --

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK TERRACE
dialogues.text: High on the great boulders which loom decoratively over the swimming pool, JOEY (a PROP MAN) can be seen arranging the dummies in a long row on the rocks. He calls down:

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Fine, Joey. (he turns to

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So how do they look?  71 ZIMMER (contd. ) (after a beat) Stupid, that’s how they look...

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (coming on strong) Darling, this marvelous bash you're giving him... As I hear it, your whole idea was to get Hannaford in touch with the new generation...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: And vice versa --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: And that’s why so few of your guests are his own age -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Most people of Mister Hannaford’s age are too old for him...

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDE TERRACE
dialogues.text: A minority group of well-established Hollywood citizens.  72

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
dialogues.text: (winding up a little speech) ++. Screen Director's Guild waiting around on their tired old asses for the phone to ring. His ass is tired too, but he don’t sit on it. Jake gets out and hustles.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Sure -- just to keep up all of this...

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CITIZEN, (VOGEL)
dialogues.text: Who says he’s keepin’ it up? I hear he’s in trouble...

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Power...

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CITIZEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Look at the dictators... Symphony conductors -- look at them. Power -- that’s the answer. Y’don’t keep goin’ just playin’ golf. Geta country under you, or a whole orchestra -- that charges up the old batteries...  73 FOURTH CITIZEN (contd. ) He stops -- catching sight of JAKE, who has come up behind them, drink in hand... How about it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (a sardonic lifting of one eyebrow) Give me an orchestra and we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: (who has been lurking B.G.) And go on playing the same old piece?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (with perfect serenity) Nice to see you, kid. JAKE smiles sweetly at him...

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: We do chug along a little, Mr. Simon, with the times...

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: Which times? -- and who are you?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: There never was an artist yet who didn’t work from memory.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The Baron is in charge of metaphysics.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (turning on SIMON) And who got him an invitation?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: “Confrontation” is the word, Abie. Take it up with our hostess.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Zarah? She must be nuts. JAKE has just caught sight of a cute little blonde -- a very young one...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Mother seems to think a little young blood’1l be good for us --  75

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
dialogues.text: (lecherously registering the young

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: She could be right at that!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She’s always right... Excuse me, fellas, but I think we got ourselves a confrontation... He starts moving in on his target. The CITIZENS chuckle appreciatively as they sit watching his progress.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: He’s got another motivation --

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
dialogues.text: I’ll say --

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: (soberly) The one that matters. He’s in love --

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Get off it, he’s too old for that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIE RICH’S GROUP 76

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Some people never are. You'd be surprised at how much mustard’s being cut in the old people’s home.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CITIZEN
dialogues.text: So who’s he in love with -- Zarah?

dialogues.speaker: FIFTH CITIZEN
dialogues.text: The movies.

dialogues.speaker: KLEE
dialogues.text: (in his solemn Dutch accent) I dig... It is not that he not make female stars -- it is just that he did not make them stars --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: That's my whole thesis --

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Great thesis, the old man can still score --

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: Who says so -- ?  77

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: How he scores -- who he scores with... That, my friends, gets us into some very interesting country...

dialogues.speaker: THE BLONDE, (IN A TIGHT GROUP SHOT)
dialogues.text: JAKE lays a hand on OSSIE’S shoulder. He turns back to the

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Hi -- !

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Jake -- I think you know Ossawatomie Duluth...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ill-met by candlelight, proud Titania! Ossie... we like your little friend.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (putting an arm around her) Not his, Skipper. She’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (disregarding this, bending his good ear to her and oozing charm) What’s your name, sweetie?  JULIE RICH’S GROUP 78

dialogues.speaker: THE BLONDE
dialogues.text: Mavis Henscher.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: --. Oh, yes, his partners are female. Certainly... But which females?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You tell us -- albinos with wooden legs?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's Sunday, Mavis... you’ll be flying down with us to Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (THE BLONDE)
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Piedras Negras.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Bulls.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Dangerous breed, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: One of them once killed a friend of ours --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (closing in for the kill) Tomorrow we’re going to see what happens to our new boy.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (losing patience) So the old man has a kink or two -- what of it?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: (quietly serious) The old man is a destroyer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: What he creates, he has to wreck. It's a compulsion.  80

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: It’s a theory.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: I’ve got names and dates... The folder she’s holding is, indeed, rather suggestive of a dossier. But before we can hear more of this --

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Gee, I don’t know... I’ve got school on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (grinning at the others) I‘ll write a note to the teacher.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK TERRACE, (UNDER THE ROCKS)
dialogues.text: ZIMMER, his make-up box at his side, sitting glumly in front of his dummies, all arrayed before him...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: How could I -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Come on in and have a drink, Zimmie --

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: I don’t know these people. Why they’s leadin’ actors nowadays -- stars even -- I don’t know their names.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (phone still to his ear, he idicates ZIMMER’S dummies) Y‘don’t know his name --

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: John Dale?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (with grim satis- faction) Oscar. That’s his real name... In his school days whataya think he was famous for -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Fornication.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (with grim satis- faction) We got us somebody tonight who’s gonna tell us all about it -- (into phone) Yeah?  82

dialogues.speaker: BERTOLUCCI
dialogues.text: (looking up at the dummies ) Quite impressive, I just say. (he indicates the dummies )

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: So is Mr. Dale. To look at him you'd swear he was real.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (speaking into JAKE'S ear, the full Mafioso) New information -- about Dale...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Well, Uncle Matthew?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We found out where he comes from -- A big, rich family out in Iowa...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How do you like those apples? Your starving orphan went to boarding school --  Silence... 83

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We got one of his teachers. Want to see him?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Sure. Pipe him aboard, Uncle Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He’s coming out with Billy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Fine. Billy’s bringing Max --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, when’s he joining the party? (something in MATT'S eye stops her)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Any word from Texas?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I sent a car out to the airport...  Another short silence... He smiles sweetly at them all and moves away...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Jake -- Can I start the screening? Half the kids are in there waiting...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Think some of them went to expensive boarding schools? Give ‘em three reels or so, and pass among ‘em with a tin cup.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: The Hannaford Mafia isn’t looking very festive --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I wish they’d go home...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Trouble?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Four days... that’s a long time, Brooksie.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Till what? MAVIS THE BLONDE dances up to JAKE with another stiff whiskey. He accepts it gratefully. He urges her away... Then turns back to JAKE.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks, sweetie... Where’s your former boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (moving into scene) He’s here and your going to the movies --

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (firmly) Just follow the crowd... What's Friday?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Friday we close down.  86

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Jesus... A crowd of guest passes by on the way to the screening... You can’t finish the picture in four days --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) I’ve been over-schedule before. Let’s drink to that...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: How many times have you been broke, Skipper? A short, tense pause...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: At my present age, Brooksie -- just once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights dim out, there are the usual stirrings and throat-clearings... Then, on the screen we resume: HANNAFORD’S FILM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to this (part-time) projection room is important: when people open it, their silhouettes move across the screen. THE ACTRESS is the first to make such an entrance and, as she finds herself a place, is the cause of interested attention... Later there’s another interruption: the opening door (the square of light blanking out part of the screen -- the crouching and ducking silhouettes as new arrivals sneak heavily into the room). This time it’s JULIE RICH with a couple of journalist colleagues. They make a dash for it into the darkest corner of the room. Here, there aren’t any chairs, but the view of the screen in unimpeded, so they sit on the floor. ROGER and DENISE KLEE (a film-making partnership) are squatting nearby, their backs to the wall. Soon others in the room become aware of a low and rather venomous buzzing from the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (addressing JULIE

dialogues.speaker: RICH
dialogues.text: Don’t try to lay that on us --

dialogues.speaker: KLEE
dialogues.text: (total incredulity) You can say almost anything else about him --  They do, but for the moment they shut up. THE FILM continues... 88

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (elaborately patient, wind- ing up an argument ) If -- and I say “if,” mind you -- actually going to bed with a boy is the only definition you'll accept --

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS GUESTS
dialogues.text: Shhh -- !

dialogues.speaker: CASSIE
dialogues.text: Do you mind -- ?  89 A WINDOW IN THE “PROJECTION ROOM” OTTERLAKE stands looking in at the FILM being projected now for the guests...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: Hey -- put Hannaford there... There, where you’re standing.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Come on, cooperate...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: The reflection in the glass -- The face and the film inside -- a real Hannaford set-up! During this OTTERLAKE has laughingly urged JAKE into place. Now, as the camera turns, he fills in the lull with a quotation:

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “These, your actors, were all spirits- And are melted into air... Into thin air...”  90 JAKE has started a long pull at his drink but is interrupted by the voice of JULIE

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Tatum, Fryer, Leigh... Branch Sutter... Garvey... He smiles at her... Then, after a short silence:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Absent friends.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: And John Dale... All made by you --. Funny. We don’t see one of those men tonight at your party.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Tonight is for the freaks and snoops, lady -- If you’ll excuse us, please...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go in and see the movie, lady -- like everybody else? They wait for her to go... She does.  91

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: “Thin air...”

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “And like the baseless fabric of this vision, shall dissolve...” Did you know they had dissolves in Shakespeare? (playing it up a little for the benefit of the camera) Sure he does: he knows everything in Shakespeare. “The Hannaford family curse -- ”

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And he knows everything about the Hannafords; that’s my curse...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: We all know about old Grandad, Junius the First -- “The great Irish tragedian in the tinseled toga -- “

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The Shakespeare comes from him, all right.  92

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Handed down, with a few other things -- “Booze and the Bard” -- Right?... As for the booze part of it -- Well, if he hasn’t quite made it asa rummy -- nobody can say he hasn’t tried!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m seeing little pink directors at this very minute.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: But Junius -- Ah, “there was a most distinguished souse”... Another line of yours.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That's what’s so nice about Brooksie -- I don’t have to repeat myself, he does it for me...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (continuing to quote) “ -~ BR noble Roman shanty Irishman; Sure, even when he cut his wrists and killed himself...” (looking around) We've lost our camera, haven’t we?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You’re losing me.  Pause... A pause... 93

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “Like Seneca, old Junius bled to death in a bathtub -- one of the few times he ever sat in one. But Junius Junior -- ” (that’s your daddy) “He even made it into High Society -- a pioneer among the micks, blazing the trail for the Kellys and the Kennedys... Piss-elegant. He chose the chandelier...”

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A human tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: That's me, Skipper.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had the chandelier.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve got everything. In the old Hollywood Hotel it was... They found him, one Sunday morning, hanging from it. After which you had to go to work for a living... As a prop man, etcetera...  94

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah... you got it all.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I’m the Authority. (Is there -- behind the complacency of that statement -- an overtone of old affection still remaining? If so, it rings a little false in JAKE'S ears... Somehow his young friend has staked out a claim of ownership)... He looks at him with something very cold in his eyes... OTTERLAKE smiles back at him with proprietory approval... OTTERLAKE (contd. ) So... what do we do next?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We never know, do we? A pause... JAKE is in a sort of reverie... This has commenced earlier and comes from thoughts far removed from family anecdotes...  He raises his glass as 95 JAKE (contd. ) We're feeling fine -- it’s early morning --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Not quite yet.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is a flash-back... You just happen to notice somebody trying to drown himself. Some young pink nobody ever heard of. And how's this? After you dry him out, you try to get him interested in staying dry... Hell, you can recite that story backwards. And it’s lousy -- I can’t get him interested in anything. Everything’s a drag, man -- Be a movie actor? That just bores him to death... He doesn’t die, though; no, he’s cured of that. He merely kicks me rather sharply in the groin and walks away... though offering a toast. Speaking of suicides.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Come on, Skipper -- let’s go to the movies... They start away together.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG ROOM
dialogues.text: One group (among all the groups) clustered around LUCAS, or some other CINEASTE... He’s holding up his pocket tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: FROM OTHER CINEASTES
dialogues.text: Listening to the recorded voices.

dialogues.speaker: AN EARNEST VOICE
dialogues.text: (on the playback) ... Reflection of your attitude -- right, Mr. Hannaford? God isn’t dead -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (playback) Well, kid -- He’s certainly Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: What’s that about?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: One of my tapes. I’ve donated them to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Tapes -- from that book you're doing?  97

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: From the book we're not doing... I’m the little corner store, Abe, that has to give way to the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: You’re the only big director who ever tried to write about him.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I had to stop trying.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: But you two are friends... Close friends --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (lurking at OTTER- LAKE’S shoulder) That's what interests me: just how close you are...

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Abe, this is Juliette Rich, the distinguished critic. Abe Vogel, the dean of Hollywood agents... Miss Rich is doing a “study in depth” -- and she’s so far down she’s got the bends. (turning to the

dialogues.speaker: TAPE RECORDER
dialogues.text: What happened to the tape?  Laughter... OTTERLAKE grins and continues: 98

dialogues.speaker: THE CINEASTE
dialogues.text: I’m changing it.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. I know all the material ... Religion? Here it is, The Gospel According to Jake: “God the Gather is an old Jew invented by a lot of other old Jews in a hopeless attempt to put down the Jewish Mother.” He says that’s what it’s all about -- the whole new scene... Even his movie --

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (cutting in sharply) How’s that again -- ? His mov --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (cutting her off in turn, very quickly) The kids -- they're all turned on to Her...

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: The Jewish mother?  More laughter... Total silence follows that... The crowd is startled 99

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (Louis Armstrong or Flip Wilson) God? -- She sure is a mother -- !

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (unsmilingly) You said about his mov --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (now it’s his turn to cut her off) We don’t talk about the movie. by his sudden appearance, and also (JAKE himself feels) a bit dashed by the abruptness of his tone... He smiles his most benevolent and priestly smile. Try the Baron here... Under torture he might squeal a little. He writes the scripts --

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: So Mr. Hannaford likes to say --  This stops her dead in her tracks... 100

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (to THE BARON) Then this is your idea-- ?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (amiably blank) What idea?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (losing her cool a little, she has a hunch they're putting her on) Don’t pretend to be stupid. You're the brainy one in this famous club of yours -- or “Clan: or whatever you call it --

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: It's a highly informal organization.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: That tape we were hearing -- the subject was God... Is He a member?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She.  101

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: You heard the man, lady.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: I heard you imitating him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He does other people better.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (as Jack Benny) Well -- It came to Our Prophet in a blinding flash of light, that Old Mister White Whiskers has shot his last thunderbolt, so... we’re back where we started -- (his own voice) -- Back to Mamma. (playing to the gallery) His words, mark you -- The Last of The Male Chauvinists --

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: (a sneer out of the shadows) I like him as Hannaford. That’s his beat. You’d swear he is Hannaford.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (with an icy smile) That's real nice, Jack -- coming from you.  JAKE intervenes, patching up a nasty little moment between 102 the two young directors. Laughter and some applause...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We’re all ruled by the wind, aren't we, lady? So if the Lord is a lady, and God's will is Her will -- then we can relax, can’t we? And stop expecting the universe to be logical.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Thus spaketh Jake. JULIE RICH is slightly dazed by all this glib recitation, but she makes a quick, if slightly lopsided recovery.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (indicating

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: And how does your disciple feel about the new film --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (cutting this subject off again) He’s the apostle, lady.  (JAKE, of course, is putting her on; and OTTERLAKE plays up to 103 it -- drawing, as usual, on his powers of memory and mimicry)

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Sure, just like St. Paul... (aside to JAKE) I know the lyrics for that one, too. (in JAKE'S voice) Paul was a big man, y'know. He put it all together, packaged it -- (in his own voice) Sounds like a producer. (as JAKE again) Well, kid, he got the final cut. Jesus was dead -- the subject was in public domain when old Paul dreamed up Christianity, and stuck then “anity” into Christ --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: As long as I’m still twitching, Brooksie -- you ain’t gonna stick it into me. JULIE RICH does not fail to catch the veiled aggression in this last...  104 (During this last MAVIS, OTTERLAKE’S young blonde has tripped into scene bearing a stiff drink for JAKE) OTTERLAKE glances quickly at JAKE... who is smiling at JULIE with an air

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (to JAKE) Isn’t that just what he’s doing? ... Otterlake’s new picture is breaking the house record at the Music Hall, and when his own production company goes public, they say he’1ll walk away with forty million dollars...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: And you'll say I stole it all from Mr. Hannaford... I’1l never walk away from that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (sibylline) Yes... you two have to stick together. of perfect benevolence...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Please don’t tell us what you mean by that.  105

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: (with a leer) Whatever it means, you hadn’t ought to be impertinent to an Apostle...

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (with some petulance) Hey, this is a drag -- how did we get off into religion -- ?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: To get away from movies. (back to JULIE) The name of the game, lady.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (pouring a little oil on the troubled waters) We should get away from both. A mystery should be left in peace.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (a voice from the outlying suburbs of this group) Mystery -- ?  Miss RICH thinks she has a smart answer to that one: 106

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Games are only fun till someone loses.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (irritated to find himself so much out of his depth) What mystery?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (smiling at

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m a good loser, lady -- a lovely loser. (to VOGEL) Movies and friendship... those are mysteries... (was there just a tiny sting in the last?... Anyway, his tone brightens abruptly) And religion... The Baron’s into that but also I know his material -- (as THE BARON) “A mystery may reveal, it never explains.”  107

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Like Mr. Hannaford --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quickly, brightly) Right, sweetie. Just like me and God. He started to go, but turns back for the curtain line: If it weren’t for the difference of sex, how could you tell us apart?

dialogues.speaker: THE FILM
dialogues.text: Continues... And now, another interruption: There is a low buzz of interest as JAKE’S shadow is cast upon the screen... Drink in hand, he takes a chair at the side of the room and sits there watching... From the SOUND-TRACK he can hear his own voice (picked up on the set by his own micro- phone -- speaking from behind his own camera) issuing directions to the actors -- giving quiet but insultingly obscene commands to the actor JOHN DALE by way of guiding the erotic action... (The sequence is the one on the rusty wreck of a bed in the back-lot of the abandoned movie studio)... Suddenly a voice is heard in the projection room itself:

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: (hoarsely vulgar) We oughta be coming soon to that shot where he walked off The picture... huh, Mr. Hannaford?...  109 No reply to this from JAKE... THE VOICE in the audience persists --

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER VOICE
dialogues.text: Sure; they got it all on filn, y‘know,... I was there; Jake went right on cranking: the whole thing -- where he marches straight out of the studio bare-assed... Again, no comment from JAKE... And now, as he sits watching it, we come to that moment in the action (THE GIRL’S scissors on THE BOY’S hair) when JOHN DALE jumps up off the bed, strides through the mass of movie equipment, off the set and away... JAKE'S VOICE can be heard on the SOUND-TRACK (of the FILM) ordering his camera- men not to cut... A wave of half stifled laughter here in the projection room accom- panies this... Then a  110 (contd. ) slightly embarrassed silence... Suddenly the screen goes blank. A pause...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Let’s keep going. But nothing happens. In the shadows we can just make out JAKE as he turns an inquiring look in the direction of the projectionist. Then the door opens... But this time, no bright light is thrown on the screen. All lights, in fact, have been turned off, and what enters now through the door is an immense comic birthday cake -- a fabrication of film cans crowned with a perfect forest of kitchen candles. “Ohs!” And “ahs!” (rather campily) from the crowd... THE BARON is in charge of ceremonies (the gag is clearly his)...  111 Everyone gathers in a circle around the mass of candles, They are big kitchen candles, far too numerous to blow out in the traditional single puff. The buzz and chatter trails away into silence...

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Nobody was sure just how many candles...

dialogues.speaker: JESSEL
dialogues.text: Looks like the Chicago fire.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. ZARAH, (INTER-CUT WITH JAKE)
dialogues.text: (candle flames between their faces and the lens)

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: You should make a wish...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) What for? (Why is that faint shadow of pain in JAKE'S eyes?)

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: (boringly raucous) Better start blowing -- !  112

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: Think you can make it, Hannaford? JAKE has caught JULIE'S eye...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Take a lotta blowing -- I’d say it’s a job for Miss Rich. She’ll huff and she’ll puff, and she’ll blow the house down -- JULIE, exchanging looks with JAKE, takes a puff at the candles -- none go out. Laughter... Everybody starts blowing... Finally the last candle is out.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s get back to the film... A PAUSE... Nothing happens. Has something happened to the machine? No, it’s a black-out -- The whole ranch is in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: darkness.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: “We didn’t just blow out the candles, we blew out a fuse!”...”Too Many camera lights -- it’s the generator -- He’s got his own out here...”  113 OTTERLAKE moves next to JAKE as he comes out of the projection room... AL (ever the eager aspirant to full membership in the CLUB) closes in from another direction.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (in one of his British voices) By God, Hannaford! This will shake the chancelleries of Europe!

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (comically portentious) This is no accident, Otterlake, it’s sabotage. The “sun-guns” still work, of course. There is much flaring and glaring of these as JAKE, with MAVIS glued to his side, moves through the dark, crowded rooms... OTTERLAKE and AL follow.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (another voice) Sabotage, eh? Whom do you suspect -- that, er... cineaste? He indicates JACK SIMON

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He wouldn’t know his cineaste from a hole in the ground. No, probably a midget with a grudge...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF FLASHES, (ALL OVER THE DARKENED RANCH)
VOICES
dialogues.text: “Y'getting anything?” "Not with color.” "Black and white, maybe...?” "Hey! -- Those South Americans -- They got tons of it. And Otto...” "Black and white? See how much we can borrow -- “ "How much’11 you pay?” "There’s a regular price -- “ "Not tonight there won't be -- ” CALB (the handy-man) having confessed his inability to deal with break-down of the ranch’s generator, quickly organizes a whole bunch of lamps and lanterns from the stables. Thus, we have been watching (in a SERIES OF DIFFERENT ANGLES) the gradual re-illumination of the party...

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: Saw your film...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: You can’t see anymore of it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (looking around for JAKE who has suddenly vanished) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: No lights, no projection, dum dum... (to SIMON) Anyway, I didn’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: You will, kid, you will... Lemme tell ya what I think of it --

dialogues.speaker: JACK NICHOLSON
dialogues.text: Hey, how about that drive-in -- ? That last little town you pass on the way out here --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Find one of the stooges somebody they’1l listen to --

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you, kid? You’‘re the one that’s good at imitations --

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Do Jack Benny.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (with the same hard smile as before) Get us a drink, sweetie, go on -- two big ones...  MAVIS retreats into the shadows... 116

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How’ll I find you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: Just look for Hannaford, he glows in the dark. Right, Brooksie?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to SIMON) What you imitate is him -- The man himself. Your idea of him: the bullfights and the big game -- the whole macho bit...

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: The truth is, as a macho he ain’t all that much. He just likes be with ‘em. That chest ain’t near as hairy as he’d like you to think. Your guy’s a big, pink lobster -- nothing’s really tough except the shell.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Now what...? I ask you what’s so tough about you -- and you ask me if I wouldn’t like to find out; and then we entertain the guests with an old-fashioned Hollywood first fight?

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: If that’s how you want it, kid.  117

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Old-fashioned is the word, all right! Even the way you do Jake -- Maybe he was like that thurty years ago...

dialogues.speaker: JACK SIMON
dialogues.text: I’‘1l give him forty years -- My Jake'll still lick the shit outta his. JAKE has been overhearing this... Now he steps for- ward out of the shadows, pushing JACK SIMON and (with surprising speed) rabbit punches him... SIMON doubles up for a minute; and at this, BILLY (with equally surprising speed) seizes the opportunity to blackjack him senseless ... Then, with a wicked grin, he defuses his weapon, which turns out to be an ashtray wrapped in a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (putting the ashtray back on a table) I wasn’t even here.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to BILLY) What the hell did you do that for?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Putting a little extra zing in the old lobster’s clay Brooksie.  118 MUSIC strikes up bravely in the darkness. OTTERLAKE stares at him... He turns and starts away...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: JAKE (contd. ) We'd do the same for you. We imitation Hannafords have got to stick together. PAT’S VOICE (calling) What happened, Jake? Dale -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do you think? Who knows? Johnny Dale, maybe. He could have snuck into the generator with his little monkey wrench...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Jake, I gotta talk to you...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sure, Billy. First take care of the wounded while I say hello to Mother.  He goes...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (starting away) A couple wranglers can take him to the local first aid. We’re donating his motorcycle to charity.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I hope you aren’t proud of that, Skipper.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: THE LIBRARY, (FOR THE TV INTERVIEW)
