dialogues.text: Surrounded by OTTO’S skillful arrangement of candles, MISS VALESKA is continuing her ordeal:

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Okay, Zarah -- ! No romance!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We aren’t rolling.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (after another heavy little silence) I do wish you could bring yourself to open up on Jake just a little... Professionally at least --  120

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: HER VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: JAKE has come up behind the camera, and has been watching this last.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We don’t have much of a part, do we, Beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: We made just half of a picture together.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: In Austria, and what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Hitler -- that’s what happened.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: He threw you out, Zarah?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Miss Valeska threw him out -- Eventually. The rest of us, of course, were in there behind her, I was way behind...

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: But you did liberate the Ritz.  121

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Her friend Ernest put in for that one -- but I was three bottles ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (who never gives up) Pretend he isn’t here, darling -- Let’s have the truth about him...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Every man contains within himself the whole condition of humanity.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Write that down, somebody.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Somebody did.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to FIONA) She gave me the book.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford always enjoys pretending to be ignorant.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And spoilt the present by telling me who gave it to her. Mr. Ossawottomie Duluth --  (These two are not so innocent as to have forgotten that the cameras exist, but by now they honestly 122

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (quickly, scenting smut ) Ossie -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The queers adore great women. They like all women. They’re the only sex that does.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Come on -- !

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (turning to her) True: real men never like us. Men only like men... don’t care about them.)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (turning back to FIONA as he gets caught up in his theme ) And women... keep us away from each other --

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Ah... “But if I cut him off,” we ask ourselves, “cut him off from all his good companions -- what will be left of him?” (pause) “An amputee, perhaps? An emotional basket case?”  123

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You chop away all the same... A month's silence. Half a man is better than none. He moves away... A CAMERA following... The voices of the TV people retreating as he leaves them behind: OTTO’S VOICE (the Cameraman; after a beat) We start again? FIONA’S VOICE (murderous ) You haven't been shooting? What about these other cameras? OTTO’S VOICE They’re on their own, of course. FIONA’S VOICE Well, who the hell gave them permission -- ? JAKE moves to OTTERLAKE, taking ["Broke” } the drink out of his hand...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Who told you I was broke?  124

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Well... Billy said you’ve lost the boat -- For a moment there’s a baleful look in JAKE’s eye as he looks up from his drink.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He did, did he...? How about the roof over my head, Brooksie, how dos that grab you?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: The ranch -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Out in the snow, kid -- over the hill... and down Dale -- But let’s not ever speak of Master John Dale, shall we? Ever.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (covering his extreme discomfort with a flare of temper) Dale -- ! That’s what really bugs you, isn’t it? With all your troubles -- Jesus, what’s one lousy leading man?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Less than the dust, kid, from my chariot wheels.  125

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I‘ll drink to that --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (staring into his glass) You’1l never catch up with me.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m told... JAKE raises his eyes to him... OTTERLAKE may have expected some slight acknowledgement of this delicate compliment, but JAKE'’s look is curiously withdrawn, and almost sly.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Cute... very cute. MUSIC again... (alter- nately, Flamenco and New Orleans jazz). It continues throughout the following:

dialogues.speaker: THE SLATE BOY
dialogues.text: Take twenty-three.  126 He leaps nimbly out of scene... MISS VALESKA’s candles still glow enchantingly between the flowers... but no MISS VALESKA!

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: She’s gone!

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: Sun-gun...!

dialogues.speaker: SCRIPT GIRL
dialogues.text: Well... maybe she’1ll be back.

dialogues.speaker: OTTO
dialogues.text: (deep over-lap) I wouldn’t use a light like that on Miss Valeska...

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (under hear breath) What could a light do to her -- ? She’s had so many face lifts, she’s ready to choke...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the doorway.  Silence... All the knocked

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: fight is out of FIONA. 127 FIONA (0.S.) (contd.) (appealing to her crew) All I did was mention the word "SEX"...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: There wasn’t any.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (floundering) I’m sorry, I...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: You meant with Mr. Hannaford, I suppose. (making a simple statement) There wasn’t ever... No sex at all.  128 ["MAFIA 2 + 3”]

dialogues.speaker: THE TERRACE
dialogues.text: MAGGIE has succeeded in intercepting JAKE and moves him toward a gathering of the Clan.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Frankl’s here -- he just got in from Texas...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (entering scene from another direction) I brought that teacher, Jake; I got him waiting at the pool... JAKE stops in front of HYMIE FRANKL (a long- time, part-time member of the organization).

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: Lousy, awful trip...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (turning to BILLY) And you -- ?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (startled) Jake! I just told you...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) That's kept you busy -- just collecting school-teachers?  129 (BILLY hopes his rueful grin will signal a reminder to JAKE that he’s also been occupied with SIMON... But there’s no indication that this registers.)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: (plaintively) Hey, can I please get myself something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Didn't they feed you, Joey?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: All they do on airplanes is feed you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: Turbulence...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) You threw up? Give him some candy, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (patiently) I didn’t “collect” the teacher, Jake, he met me at the screening --  He stops. He knows the answer... AL is behind him. 130

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quickly, quietly) With Max -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: Look, Jake, those oil guys, they want no part of us.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a short silence, cheerfully) Neither does Max -- Right, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (joining the group) Max David -- ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: That dirty crook -- who needs him?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We do...  131

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Max? -- he’s so crooked he’s got rubber pockets so he can steal soup. He looks around -- not really hoping for a laugh and certainly, not getting it... They turn to find him standing nearby...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Our best chance was that oil money...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: And Otterlake -- what about him?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, what about me?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (a lightning quick cover-up) Brooksie! -- we just wondered if you knew about the drive-in?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (chiming in) Yes, we're screening the rest of the --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (cutting them off) He’s seen the movie --  132

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Not everything.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (with his nervous little laugh) Well, we don’t have everything...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Leave it to Jake. Pretty soon you'll have too much.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You bet! We’ve had our troubles before...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (arranging an exit) Get you a drink, Skipper?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (acknowledging the tact) Thanks, Brooksie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (when OTTERLAKE has left, lower- ing her voice) At Max's studio he’s the golden-haired boy, isn’t he --  133

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He’s got his own company...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Tied in with Max --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's what I mean, Billy --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (looking at BILLY) He blew it, Maggie... Must be all that candy he eats.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Me -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to BILLY) You were the one with Max -- where is he?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not here, that’s where he is -- ! (getting a bit querulous) -- And what the hell’s the candy got to do with it? JAKE, lifting another long drink, looks at BILLY with his most sweetly patient, sacerdotal smile...  134

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Could be it’s softening your brain, Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It's for the sugar... Since I got off that stuff... His eye is on JAKE’s drink... his anger makes it possible to screw up his courage and mention a very delicate matter: And speaking of which... JAKE (who knows BILLY is about to be censor- ious about the liquor) cuts in swiftly knocking him off balance:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Wasn’t very smart, y’know -- poor- mouthing like that in front of Otterlake. Know who he is, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Of course I do -- I’ve seen his pictures --

dialogues.speaker: FRANKL
dialogues.text: Big hits, both of ‘em --  135

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to MATT) Tell him who he is, Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Brooksie’s old man owns half the trees in Canada.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And y'know what Billy told him? He told him we’re in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, aren’t we? JAKE turns back to give him another steady, almost pitying look.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (very patiently) When we talk poor to the rich, William, they jump to conclusions. They think we’re getting ready for a touch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (hushed) And that’s what we're doing?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That could have been the general idea -- Till Uncle Billy loused it up on us.  136 Poor BILLY turns away...

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (lurching out of the shadows) Mr. Hannaford --

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: No more questions, junior --

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: As it happens, I did one of the earliest really positive critical appraisals --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, horray for you.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: Well, he’s bound to feel some gratitude --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Brooksie Otterlake’s a chum... (gently, friendly -- but with a delicate hint of severity) We don’t hustle our chums for dough, kid. We’re kinda strict about that.  137 A tiny silence...

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) But, Mr. Hannaford -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, kid?

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but... didn’t I just hear you saying --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (patting PISTER gently on the cheek) Always remember... that your heart is God’s little garden... He smiles at him and ambles off into the darkness... The others trailing along after him or drifting away in different directions -- Except for MATT who moves threateningly up to the flabbergasted

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That tape recorder running -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: But there is a camera somewhere... MATT turns sharply and squints suspiciously into the shadows... Seeing nothing, he gives PISTER another dirty look and leaves... ZIMMER’S VOICE Don’t let it bother you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PISTER, turning near- sightedly in the direction of the voice, finds ZIMMER standing just behind him...

dialogues.speaker: ZIMMER
dialogues.text: Studying a man like Jake Hannaford -- that’s an experience. Don’t you miss it. Stick with the job. (dropping his voice to a tone at once confiden- tial and reassuring) Eat a little shit, Mr. Pister...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PART OF THE TERRACE
dialogues.text: Standing, rather uncertainly, in front of JAKE is DOCTOR BURROUGHS. (If he’d been born earlier, DOCTOR BURROUGHS would have been the last man in town to give up spats:)

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford -- Doctor Bradley Pierce Burroughs --

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Pease.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (with his brightest smile) Pease?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Bradley Pease Burroughs. (nervous laugh) Not that it matters! (holding out his hand) How do you do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The Doc here is a professor of English Literature in the Framistan Boarding Academy for Boys --

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (correcting him) Clivedale -- that’s the name of the school...  140

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He also teaches dramatics.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (merrily) And who do you think was my star pupil? But of course, we knew him then as “Oscar” --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (with a leer) Tell about Aunt Daisy -- with the funny hats. BURROUGHS is becoming increasingly aware of the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: I don’t know that they were funny...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She raised him, you told me -- and ever since the first day he could walk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing apart watching the curious little scene at some distance.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: BURROUGHS treats JAKE a smile compounded of pity and 141

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH VALESKA
dialogues.text: (to OTTERLAKE) What’s the point of this? MATT’S VOICE (0.S.) --. Putting on shows. All dressed up in Auntie’s gowns and hats and dresses --

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to MAGGIE) And the way Dale tells it, he didn’t even want to be an actor...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sure; that was supposedly Jake's idea -- He practically forced him... BURROUGHS’ VOICE (0.S.) Down there in Acapulco...?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, what was he doing? I mean, besides getting stoned -- to  142

dialogues.speaker: C.U. BURROUGHS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Affection for his old student and the assurance that JAKE will be understanding.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (meaningfully) He made the trip just to see you...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: .--. And the change of name?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: For that, I’m afraid, we’ll have to blame Oscar Wilde.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Do go on, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Well -- we had this teacher... It was one of those unpleasant little scandals...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ZARAH...she turns away. MAGGIE and OTTERLAKE

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This teacher was a faggot?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE AND BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: 143 BURROUGHS’ VOICE (0.S.) Well...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Does all this matter?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I think it does to Jake...

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hannaford... BURROUGHS, increasingly uneasy about all these busy camera surrounding him, coughs and purses his lips. The story concerns my school: I’m in no position to publish abroad a petty --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (over-lap) Publish and be damned, Doctor. Look -- they’ve run out of film -- you can speak off the record... This last is accompanied by a quick glance (almost a wink!) Into the lens of the second camera which is following...  A brief silence -- 144 BURROUGHS is still flushed with the excitement of being the center of all this attention, but by now he’s feeling quite nervous about the particular turn this multi-media interview is taking. JAKE gives him his steady “man to man” look: (A good equivalent to the straight arm on the shoulder).

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Dale himself was in no way involved; but among the boys, there was a good deal of morbid conversation, I’m afraid, on unhealthy subjects. As you can imagine -- the name “Oscar”...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (in a tone of the most perfect warmth and understanding) What happened to that teacher?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: We let him go, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (still gently, but closing the trap) Let him go? What about the police?  145

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (startled) The police? The poor man was sick, Mr. Hannaford.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Those young boys -- they weren't sick when he finished with ‘em? (hardening) That’s a prison offense, isn’t it -- How many minors do you have to corrupt?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (shocked) I hope you’re not worried about Dale...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You think I should be?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t that depend, Mr. Hannaford, on your own personal interest?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a very short beat) What are you driving at, Burroughs?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Why, nothing...  146

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) I’m just his director, not his Aunt Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: And I’m just his English teacher! (a self-conscious little laugh) JAKE looks at him for a moment... (He’s allowed the scene to get a little out of control; now he’s going to get back on top).

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (with the Hannaford smile) Right!

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (pulling himself together) But certainly, he has every reason to be grateful to you... (archly) And I’m sure that some day, when one of his fine performances gets the Academy Award, you'll be grateful to him.  147

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (straight into camera) Notice how careful he is not to refer to it as an “Oscar.” (back to BURROUGHS) Doctor, would you care for a dip?

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: A dip...? In the pool? What a grand suggestion!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (turning away) A little more hootch should be helpful -- I’1l be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: Good... Good. And where do I change?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (turning back) Here, Dr. Burroughs, in the sight of God; I won’t even peek.

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (absorbing this) Yes...I suppose all school teachers are prigs.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Prigs and queers.  148

dialogues.speaker: BURROUGHS
dialogues.text: (archly) Now, now, Mr. Hannaford --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Now, now, Dr. Burroughs --

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: His reaction to this curious little charade...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Big birthday surprise, eh, beautiful? He has just entered the scene... BILLY and MAGGIE follow. pause...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know the latest... (to ZARAH) Remember the way they met -- when Jake pulled Mr. John Dale out of the water? The famous would-be suicide --

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (flatly) Would-be suicides ought to be treated like drunks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (breaking in) Would-be suicide, hell: --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I was conned, Mother, it was a fake --

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: And it turns out that he doesn’t belong to you?  150 JAKE'’s smile goes a little blank.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (antagonized) Belong -- ?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: The old Chinese business, remember? You save a life -- you own that life.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Finder keepers?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Do you care?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Care? We’re free for a change, eh, Uncle Bill...? Now we’ll have some fun. BILLY smiles gratefully... MAGGIE is irritated:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to ZARAH) Jake isn’t a Chinaman --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: “Chinese,” Maggie -- No, and the kid wasn’t a suicide. He was... an actor.  151 He makes the last word sound obscene... ZARAH can’t help but notice that his eyes are glazed to avoid scrutiny, he steps behind a screen and finishes undressing...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) We don’t own people.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He wasn’t drowning -- he was auditioning.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Or disown them. That boy didn’t run away from you. He was thrown away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And sweet Holy Jesus, what a relief! Like getting rid of a bad tooth -- Right, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A monkey on my back -- He has stepped out from behind the screen (dressed now in a terry-cloth bath- robe)... ZARAH’s look has stopped him. That means a drug habit, in case you didn’t know, Mother... Sure -- something you gotta kick. And my foot was getting sore...  152

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: How will you finish it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Finish what? He’s all washed up, Mother --

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: The picture... Isn’t that what matters?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We'll finish it; eh, Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Without the kid?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We do have that footage of him bringing the clothes to her... through all that wind --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: To the girl?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after another beat, unfocussed) What about her? JULIE RICH’S VOICE (0.S.) Yes, what about her?  JULIE RICH comes into scene. Enter THE BARON... 153

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: We're all... interested. (another beat)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Neither are you... She doesn’t interest you at all. Funny, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: A scream.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: I mean, look at the record -- the big starmaker’s never been so big females --

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (holding up a length of iron pipe) Present for you... Not from me -- Zimmer. There’s a card.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (his back turned, his eyes on ZARAH) Zimmie? We oughta have a drink with Zimmie...  154

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: You fired him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I always fire him. (turning to THE

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: Anyway, on my birthday I give the presents.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: It's some kind of gag -- (he sighs) We know... You make the gags, too.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (looking at the pipe) He tells me where I can stick it?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: It's for those plastic John Dales that he made for you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Things would have been different, wouldn’t they, if Dale had been her lover -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (looking in at the door ) I got an early day, Zarah, it’s been a lovely party...  155

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (still zooming in on

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You couldn’t manage that -- It rather spoils the pattern, doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What’s this pattern shit?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: The big boss can tell you -- he knows how it goes -- How it’s supposed to go...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Well, I’m going home -- What’s that thing?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (half to herself, angrily turning away ) Zimmie's jokes -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Speaking of presents... JAKE has been rummaging in a drawer. He brings something out and, turning with it, is haulted again by MATT’s voice reading from ZIMMER'’s “birthday card”:  156

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (reading) “Have a go at the dummies, Jake -- they break even more easily than people.” After a moment’s pause, JAKE turns again and moves out to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (INCLUDING THE ACTRESS)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (making an announcement ) Gentlemen -- and Ladies... The clot of cameras thickens quickly around him... We're presenting an award... To the other half of “The Other Side Of The Wind”... the better half. A glint of alcohol in his eye, he moves toward THE ACTRESS. A bone for Pocohontas... The crowd watches in uneasy silence (THE ACTRESS very cool)...  He pauses for effect. His eyes move to THE ACTRESS. 157 JAKE (contd. ) A little curio we picked up somewhere -- A bit of our own palefaced craftsmanship: an Indian bone... The inscription goes back before all this was movie country. Just after the gold was found. The redskin population dropped pretty quickly then -- ten years and ninety thousand of ‘em just... disappeared. Well, in those good old days, our gallant honkey pioneers used to cut themselves some heads off Indian skulls and pickle the ears in whisky for souvenirs -- And on bones, like this one, they liked to write cute little jokes -- (reading the inscription) “I am off the reservation at last.” And so you are, my dear... He lays the bone down on a table next to her quite gently, and speaks quite lightly.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: We thought you might want to give this to your leading man -- right up his ass.  158

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHORT SCENES, (IMPROVISED)
dialogues.text: Between carious types... including some notable celebrities. All this (like everything else) is recorded by the documentary camera-crew, and also video-freaks)... As the party continues, the generation gap is underscored by the choice of intoxicants. Guests anywhere near HANNAFORD’s age are, of course, mostly on booze... JAKE himself is quietly putting it away in fairly Homeric quantities... At this stage, he certainly isn’t sober. (THE DWARVES are frankly drunk)...  159

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine array of trophies, a magnificent gun collection and many framed photographs (groups on safari and convivial gatherings aboard the Hannaford yacht). AL is studying one of the pictures. It shows a handsome young man tensely profiled in front of some battered targets and clay pigeons.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Who’s the joker with the cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Miguel -- He was the best of all.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Best of what?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Our bullfighters, right, Jake? We followed him for a while all over Spain.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (to JAKE, who has just entered with

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: That’s you, aiming the gun at him in the shooting gallery...  160

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Another birthday, kid. And what a party that was -- No movie buffs or bums, no spies or spooks. Just paid- up members of The Club.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (reading the sign- ture on the photo) Miguel Ortega?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: The best.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Didn't he get killed?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (grinning as he continues to study the photograph) I hope you weren’t responsible for that.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I just got that one shot at him, Brooksie, and I missed.  161

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: CBut he got the cigarette. (he starts out the door) There was never any braver.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (following THE BARON) Not in a shooting gallery.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No, he didn’t look too good in there.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I guess he didn’t quite trust you -- (he breaks off, with a quick change of tone) Drop that gun, Skipper. JAKE has indeed, picked out a rifle from his gun collection. If you're planning to celebrate this birthday on me just --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is the one that hurts, Brooksie... (OTTERLAKE is so good at dead-panning a gag that we almost wonder if he does imagine the old man is proposing some sort of lunatic duel?)  162 JAKE looks up at him, as the young director rises abruptly to his feet. Silence...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Skipper --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) This is the scene we both hoped that we'd never get to. And I don’t think it’s going to play. Not even for comedy. He raises the gun and sights along it, pointing out the window --. He pulls the trigger. It clicks. The gun is empty. He lowers it, and turns, faintly smiling to OTTERLAKE... A short silence... Then:

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: How much longer do you need?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How much longer have you got? OTTERLAKE tries to answer... JAKE gets up and leans the gun against the wall.  Silence... Silence... 163 JAKE (contd. ) Hey -- remember when you first appeared on that location of mine up in Bolivia? What is it -- just three years ago?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (forcing a chuckle) I didn’t even have the fare back home, just a second-hand tape recorder that I couldn’t work --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A raggedy-ass kid...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Skipper...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: That forty million that was mentioned...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I know, kid; let me finish your line for you. It’s still only a distant hope... How’s that for dialogue?  164 He grins at him and moves into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from the bathroom) You might just lean a little on Max David... You do the leaning, he’s gotta give.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I did set up the screening --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: So you did... He hated every frame --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: He was confused...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: He’s an idiot, Jake. You know that. They're all idiots.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He’s your idiot.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Up to a point.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Don’t be pompous, kid... Not that I don’t understand. You made the company all that loot. Christ knows I didn’t.  165

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Don’t think I’m not going to put up a fight about it. I will. JAKE comes to the door. JAKE looks at him... He starts raising the gun...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: But you don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to have to listen to Max and the rest of those stupid sods turning you down... We'll find a way... You know that, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Don’t give up the ship, Davey...?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I’m not -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you -- ? This scene will never play...  166

dialogues.speaker: THE ROW OF DUMMIES ON THE ROCKS
dialogues.text: (placed earlier in neat arrangement by ZIMMER)... The head of one of them is suddenly hit by a bullet and destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firing...

dialogues.speaker: THE TERRACE
dialogues.text: THE ACTRESS sits alone on one of them. (We are across the pool from the firing lines where the dummies are still getting blown to smithereens by the sportsmen in the window of the gun room. ) HIGGAM enters scene.

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM
dialogues.text: (out of sorts) I’ve been looking for you... She turns to look at him. HIGGAM (contd. ) Your boss sent me --

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: Not liking that word "boss"... HIGGAM’S VOICE (0.S.) I’m supposed to give you this --  167

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding out a gun...

dialogues.speaker: THE ACTRESS
dialogues.text: Another present?

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM
dialogues.text: How do I know? He just told me that he thinks you’1l know how to use it. Rising and taking the gun from him, she looks dangerous... HIGGAM beats a hasty retreat. She then raises the gun, turning to aim it directly away from the row of dummies...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S AT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: His eyes are on THE ACTRESS

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (from a place of safety) Who’s she aiming at?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Me. A shot rings out, and the lantern nearest to JAKE shatters to pieces.  168

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Hey -- !

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (falling into the hammy style of their game) Otterlake -- we never should have issued firearms to the natives. Another shot! And another lantern breaks. The group is practically blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns her gun slightly, taking careful aim --

dialogues.speaker: THE DUMMIES ON THE ROCKS
dialogues.text: Getting their plaster heads blown off!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each with a gun, firing blithely away...

dialogues.speaker: A QUICK FLASH
dialogues.text: Mother naked, scuttling frantically out of range of the flying bullets.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She’s nuts! She’s going to wreck the whole damn party --  169

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH VALESKA
dialogues.text: Jake’s done that already.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Suddenly -- Out of the blackness, a bolt of bright raspberry colored lightning (!!!) Reveals the Hannaford Ranch, the Western landscape surrounding it, and DR. BURROUGHS, crouched behind cactus, a trembling nude... The scattered dummies on the rocks look like an over-exposed negative of some unthinkable massacre... The lightning changes color -- luridly, repeatedly, and t night is hideously assaulted with noise. What has commenced, of course, is a display of fireworks. An important display -- if a bit in spirit... Guests are surprised in various attitudes and positions...  170 A mighty boom (!!!) from some larger and louder firework.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (as PATTON) Artillery. The heavy stuff. A new -- a really terrific detonation!!! The women-folk’s all safe in the stockade?

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (just beginning to dig) One of them’s been shooting at me --

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF
dialogues.text: Tiny figures, like demons from hell, can be seen on top of the house scuttling madly about in the smoke and flame...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (his Blimp character) My God, Hannaford -- there are lots of them -- little men up there -- shooting Roman candles on the roof!

dialogues.speaker: GUESTS REACTING...
dialogues.text: 171 OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (changing voices) Veteran troops, old boy -- Neo-realistics. (another voice) And the grand, old New Wave, sir. They’1ll never give up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spooked or bored, put off or turned on -- according to age group and individual temperament)...

dialogues.speaker: MORE FLASHES
dialogues.text: Exploding bouquets of light... wheels of colored flame.. of white fire...

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Look -- that sweet old lady in the tennis shoes --

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (looking wildly around) Where?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (sharply correcting him) Y’mean who.  172 AL (contd. ) (then, with lowered voice -- confidentially) Governor Reagan -- that’s who!

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (rapid transition from guardsman to Kiplingesque Tommy) Blimy -- ! This is ruddy war!

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (as a newscaster) Approached by a video-freak with an indecent suggestion (just as he was sneaking over the State line) Ronald’s wig slipped. (aside to JAKE) Is he still Governor, governor?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (grim) Whatever he is, Ronnie’s decreed a state of emergency and thrown himself on the mercy of Central Casting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another tremendous explosion!

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (turning to the bewildered PISTER to issue a grave warning) They're bringing up their symposiums...  173 AL (contd. ) (into his ear, with urgency) Critical appraisals, Pister -- in depth.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (voice change) The rot has set in, Pister. Five of our own best biographers have gone over to Preminger. (another change) They shall be stripped of their footnotes. Another burst of fire- works... something huge --

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (in a TIGHT C.U.) No, really -- ! Something seems to have caught fire --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (Nixon) Extremists from the Film Institute -- They’ve wrapped themselves in the grand old silver nitrate celluloid, and set themselves aflame.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: But what of Jane Fonda?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (a gentle pious confidence to PISTER) She’s watching us, kid -- up there...  So magnetic is his personality -- or so 174 befuddled in his victim -- that PISTER actually glances for a moment at the fiery heavens.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Now it can be told: at the outset of hostilities, Saint Jane was burnt at the stake...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (yet another voice) She has appeared since on Dick Cavett, and twice, ina vision, to Duke Wayne. They have been joined now by an interested Scottish film critic.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH FILM CRITIC
dialogues.text: Fond of fireworks, is he?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (more interested than distressed) Mr. Hannaford? He adores them...

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH FILM CRITIC
dialogues.text: (his eyes now on the roof) And those technicians -- are they really professionals?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Professionals? They’re midgets!  175

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH FILM CRITIC
dialogues.text: (making the sound of one who hopes he has understood everything) Ah...

dialogues.speaker: THE PARKING SPACE IN FRONT OF THE RANCH
dialogues.text: OTTERLAKE has one of those battery-powered megaphones used on movie sets. He is directing it upwards towards the beleaguered ranch house...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “Antinyoneeyeyonee-oh!!"

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: The war-cry. They’re dropping over Burbank like ripe plums --

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (under his breath to

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: Pass it along -- Godard has just set up a government-in-exile in Pomona. A deafening explosion -- A blinding flash of red light!!!

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Well, if Bascalucci doesn’t surrender now --  The whole sky has now 176

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (correcting his chief) Bertolucci.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (expansively) Slice him how you want him, he’s gonna be one spicy meatball. turned fiercely scarlet. OTTERLAKE raises a pair of binoculars to study the field. OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (yet another voice -- the Voice of Doom) Wayne himself -- now a barefoot friar -- has just been arrested for denigrating all over a Daughter Of The American Revolution! Jessel is demanding equal time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE has moved ahead; be seen climbing into brand-new sports car. 177 he can a beautiful, OTTERLAKE (contd. ) (in his own voice, to AL) I wonder if our leader has any idea who that belongs to --

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (lowering his voice as some other people start moving down the steps toward the parking lot) He bought it...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (incredulous) What -- ?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: It was going to be for Dale --

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: We weren’t giving much salary, so he would have got that as a bonus when he finished the picture.  178

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: He didn't, so he doesn’t...

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: And that’s the way it is. Cronkite is hastily abandoned as OTTERLAKE starts towards JAKE. Let him go -- He drives like a maniac when he’s sober.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Ah, but here’s a lady tells us that we've gotta stick together... Jake and I -- He’s referring, of course, to JULIE RICH who has come forward out of the ranch house and is steadily approaching...

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Close -- very close.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Too late now, he got away from me... He starts toward the car (AL moves off toward his) ... Then OTTERLAKE stops --  179 He turns... and moves back to her. OTTERLAKE (contd. ) And what the hell is that about?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: The farther you’re apart, the harder it will be to hide. JAKE starts up the sports car with a great roar and some erratic clashing of gears... swerves wildly into the main road... and races off toward the drive-in theatre.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Now what could we be hiding from you, lady?

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: From yourselves -- How much you really hate each other. Deathly silence... In the background, AL is seen to raise his megaphone (he has decided -- mistakenly -- to continue with another gag).  180

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (newscasting over his loud-hailer) Now here’s a late bulletin -- Marlon Brando (who, by the way, folks -- is not pregnant) has gone underground and is doing splendid work for all of us under the name of Tokyo Rose. He has quite an audience now among the parked cars in front of the ranch, but nobody laughs... After a short pause he lowers the megaphone and turns to look at OTTERLAKE: Chin up, Brooksie, they haven’t got us yet! Another pause...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: You’ve got it wrong, lady.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Yes, just slightly wrong.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: What happened to Jesus?

dialogues.speaker: THE SCOTTISH FILM CRITIC
dialogues.text: Jesus -- ? THE CRITIC is taking care that nothing shall escape his attention: BILLY’S distress by now is moving towards despair; but the elderly Hungarian, as always, is indestructably urbane.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He’s stoned out of his head --

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (to the CRITIC) A Mexican chum of ours. Almost blind, but he still makes our fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Forty years with J.J. Hannaford, and the old fart still doesn’t know any English!

dialogues.speaker: THEIR V.P.
dialogues.text: In letters of fire it proclaims:

dialogues.speaker: FFF FFF FF FFL E ETH H4
THE DRIVE-IN THEATRE
dialogues.text: The last act begins (as did act two) with --

dialogues.speaker: A BLANK MOVIE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Standing lonely in the desert country, it jumps out of the darkness under the sudden swoop of head- lights... Then --

dialogues.speaker: HANNAFORD'S FILM IS PROJECTED
dialogues.text: The images paling at first under the headlights of arriving cars. There aren't too many of these (not too many have been told about this emergency screening).

dialogues.speaker: AND WITHOUT INTERRUPTION...
dialogues.text: 183 A title: MEANWHILE —— BACK AT THE RANCH ... A flashlight’s beam, crossing a few remnant patches of the birthday party, has come to rest on a piece of black illustration board. Upon this, in the style of an old silent movie title, some wit has scrawled the words we've just been reading... We are, indeed, back the ranch, and in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the litter, an idle scattering of photographers are still idiotically photographing each other... The guests are stoned, discursive of both. Somebody snatches the illustration board from somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: “Hey, who gave you that? It’s part of the story board.” "The what?” "Come on -- I’1l show you...” THE “STORY BOARD ROOM” We've been in this room before --  184 THE “STORY BOARD ROOM” (CONT'D) -- caught glimpses of the drawings on the wall during one or another of the lamp-lit conversations... The sketches are for set-ups to be photographed for HANNAFORD’S FILM. These illustrate the action... INTERCUT CLOSE SHOTS of these are INTERCUT with the FILM itself (being shown on the screen of the drive-in-theatre) and with the following dialogue... From a tape recorder comes an unaccompanied Flamenco lament. MAGGIE and BILLY are doing their valiant best to explain their sketches to a small group of truth-seekers. HIGGAM’S VOICE --. This old man is hiding -- spying on her?

dialogues.speaker: AL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, but then she chases him, remember? MAGGIE’S VOICE He finally holes up in some old wreck of a movie prop -- PAT’S VOICE (breaking in) And now she’s pushing all this crazy shit around, you see -- trying to close the guy in, when a whole lot more of it collapses --  185 BILLY’S VOICE That’s being worked out. PAT’S VOICE So now this character is trapped --

dialogues.speaker: AL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But then we hear his voice --

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The singing? PAT’S VOICE Old Manolito -- Jake always tries to get him a job.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (on camera) But he won’t play the part --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (on camera) It won't be any midget, either.

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: (the intelligent truth-seeker) But who is he?  186

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: See the movie...

dialogues.speaker: THE FILM
dialogues.text: The VOICES continue off-screen:

dialogues.speaker: PISTER
dialogues.text: What does he represent?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Aw, just some screwy old squatters out there in the back-lot of a studio --

dialogues.speaker: DELLA
dialogues.text: But what’s he doing in the story -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You’1l have to ask Mr. Hannaford.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: But will he tell us? Silence... THE FILM continues: (THE ACTRESS on the screen alone)... JACQUELINE’S VOICE How about asking her -- ?  HANNAFORD’S_ FILM Continues... 187 PISTER’S VOICE (under his breath) What if... he’s Hannaford -- Hannaford himself?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Don’t be nuts. INTERCUT: THE FILM ITSELF AND VARIOUS GROUPS WATCHING IT. Sometimes we can see these people -- mostly they are voices over THE FILM... We are in --

dialogues.speaker: HIGGAM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let’s back up a little -- The wind it’s blowing the old movie set to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The whole world maybe...  188 KLEE’S VOICE (over-lap) It's just a wrecking job, there were machines -- ROGER’S VOICE And what about that blood on her...? KLEE’S VOICE Blood? OSSIE’S VOICE Her body -- BLACK CINEASTE’S VOICE Whatever we're supposed to think, there’s death in it... THE BARON’S VOICE My dear fellow... BLACK CINEASTE’S VOICE Man, that’s all it is -- death it’s just purely what he’s all about --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A_GROUP_ GATHERED AROUND THE BLACK CINEASTE’S CAR...

dialogues.speaker: BLACK CINEASTE
dialogues.text: (on camera) Like Simon says, under the shell he’s all mushy...  189

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: That’s mushy talk, brother.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLACK CINEASTE
dialogues.text: (to the others, indicating THE BARON) Who’s he?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CINEASTE
dialogues.text: (pink) “The Baron” -- That’s what they call him.

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Well, he is a baron.

dialogues.speaker: KLEE
dialogues.text: And he’s on all the credits for Jake’s screenplays.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: (ice-cool, with no trace of self-pity) I muse Mr. Hannaford. He has curious pleasures --

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Oh? We'd like to hear some more about those curious pleasures...  190

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Games. He likes to play games... I am a writer who stopped writing one afternoon in Budapest in nineteen twenty nine. Do I have a camera? All through the evening people have been forgetting the cameras, or trying to, or pretend- ing to try... Now THE BARON is actually looking for one. I am prepared to make a limited declaration. (he pauses, getting his thoughts together) This famous... old lion of yours -- he is not what you think, you know.

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Who called him a lion for God’s sake?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: Lions are cats. Chabrol says he’s a cat --

dialogues.speaker: CHABROL
dialogues.text: Jake is a cat that walks like a bear.  191

dialogues.speaker: BLACK CINEASTE
dialogues.text: Or a lobster -- ? That walks like a crab, sidewise...

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: You made the mask. Tear it off now and what will you find? -- Another mask. Or your own face...

dialogues.speaker: OSSIE
dialogues.text: Another mask?

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Your own face, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: MANNY
dialogues.text: A trick -- done with mirrors... Sorry go on, Baron. What’s the answer?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A magician doesn’t give any answers --

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: I’d call him a necromancer. But I do not know if he has raised the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 192 JAKE, in the sports car, sits watching the FILM... OTTERLAKE, standing not far away, turns to another car, as it pulls to a stop... Silence... The FILM continues...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (indicating the screen) Dad's done it again, hasn’t he? "Be-dimm'd the noon-tide sun; Call’d forth the mutinous winds. By his so potent art... But this... rough magic He here abjures --" (change of tone) Take back the last: it doesn’t fit...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What does “abjure” mean? You went to Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: “Give-up -- “

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That’s a suggestion?  193

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to the others) “Abjure” -- give up... he knows what it means.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I gave up on the seventh grade.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Never. Not even then... And I didn’t learn my Shakespeare in Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to the others) Mr. Otterfield wanted to be an actor -- Then he saw one of my movies -- We all read the interview...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (to the others) It can also be stated that we aren’t breaking any magic wands... (No reaction from the listening group in the car.) Wands... You’ve heard the Baron on that subject? “Every man needs two -- his own and a good one.” He’ll be hanging onto his for awhile longer --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hang onto your own, baby -- just for once.  A long silence...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (camping) He is a rough magician, isn’t he? What did I do wrong, Daddy? “Our revels now are ended..."?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You bet your sweet cheeks.  195

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits alone, watching the film... (INTERCUT: THE FILM)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S CAR
dialogues.text: JULIETTE RICH has nudged her way past OTTERLAKE and stands next to JAKE, who sits still at the wheel of his open car... She stands there looking at him... There has been the muted noise of an expensive car coming to a stop. (Per- haps we caught a glimpse of it in the background)... Now, suddenly, JULIE RICH starts back, startled, as JAKE, with that feline agility of his which can be so sur- prising, jumps out of the car. The last lurking CAMERA CREW follows him as he moves over to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FILM’S sound-track fills the pause as these two legendary figures, these famous friends confront each other...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Beautiful...  196 The banal words of the greeting seem to carry the vibration of many years of affectionate repitition. JAKE (contd. ) Going so soon...? ZARAH doesn’t speak. Wasn’t much fun for you, was it...? --. Goddam midgets...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: They’re friends of yours?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Just brought ‘em along for laughs, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Casting call... Some cockamamy notion that the Old Man oughta be a dwarf. In the movie... Don’t you think it’s better if we never see him? Her eyes have gone to the distant screen... For a moment we share her viewpoint:  197 Then --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That goes for us all, doesn’t it -- all the old men...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: JAKE waits... ZARAH makes no comment. Now he makes a sour little joke (a faint note of something close to defensiveness which we've never heard from him before).

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Heard but not seen, huh? And for the sex department... work quickly and always in the dark. He realizes that this has fallen very flat... even before he’s aware that OTTERLAKE is standing at his side.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (comic Japanese) So sorry, Sarah -- (as himself) I’m afraid our leader is a little pissed.  198

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She doesn’t like you, kid: that’s why she gave the party. She doesn’t figure I get quite enough exposure from the younger generation just from you... But I do, you know. I get quite enough. A short, tense silence... Then OTTERLAKE turns and leaves... Silence again between these two... And now, in the FILM, the lamenting wind is conquered by the song of the OLD MAN... JAKE (contd. ) That's old Manolito. We found him together... In Spain, remember...? She goes on listening for just a while longer to the old gypsies’ song... Hey, beautiful, couldn’t we fix it to see each other just a little bit less seldom.

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: With an old friend, it’s quite enough to feel he’s there -- like Gibraltar or the Eiffel Tower...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE absorbs this for moment. Then she continues: 199

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mother...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: Durability -- it can be rather fragile. Sometimes, to keep that feeling we need to keep our distance. a The bad thing is to find out that a friendship was between a couple of other people. Say goodnight for me to your actress.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (still trying to keep it bright) She’s not too happy with us, either... Well -- she was pretty good in there with the gun.  200

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: She didn’t shoot at the dummies -- JAKE doesn’t turn at her approach: he goes on looking at ZARAH.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (the faint, hopeful smile is still frozen on his face -- but no smile is in his voice) The preferred target, I guess, would have been me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Preferred by you, Mr. Hannaford? A short, ugly pause... Then: You gave her the gun...

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (suddenly exasperated) What does that mean? (Whatever has happened to her feelings about JAKE, here is a rat of a women, deserving nothing, on whom she can allow a bit of pressure to escape). What’s it supposed to mean?  201

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Don’t worry, even if she doesn’t know, she’1l tell us. (For just this moment, we’re encouraged to believe that the young lady critic has nothing to say... But we’re wrong)

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (speaking gently and quickly) Miss Valeska, you made just one picture with Hannaford?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (blank) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: Garvey was your leading man. Glen Garvey... It is true, isn’t it, that during the shooting, Hannaford had an affair with Garvey’s wife?

dialogues.speaker: ZARAH
dialogues.text: (after a short, deadly pause) We'll have to stop this, you know. This last refers to the

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY CAMERA CREW
dialogues.text: (of whose busy presence she has been increasingly aware).  202

dialogues.speaker: JULIE RICH
dialogues.text: (rapidly building to her climax, her eyes still riveted on JAKE) Men are the subject of his movies -- Whoever the man is, naturally, he has a woman -- Whoever she is -- somehow, finally, Hannaford seduces her. He must. He must possess her. That way, he possesses him...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (wearily) Okay, okay... Cut it, you guys -- That’s just what happens: the film (the documentary film of this action) ends, abruptly, like the turning off of a light. Replacing it -- A “STILL” PHOTOGRAPH OF THE GROUP (Taken by some last, lurking spy among the journalists.) But if the movie camera has stopped, the SOUND-TRACK is still recording, and we hear -- JULIE RICH’S VOICE Expensive vice, isn’t it? When he’s had his actor’s girl, he throws her away. And then, of course, he’s  203 JULIE RICH’S VOICE (contd.) Thrown away his actor, and destroyed him in the process... Perhaps that’s what he really wants -- A_hard slap! The unmistakable sound of JAKE’s sudden, brutal attack... A FLASH from a hand-held camera, roughly turned on again, and showing us nothing clear... only wild confusion and a strong impression of violence --

dialogues.speaker: AL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) They're getting all of this, you know -- on film...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit? What’s their public, for Chrissake? -- Before one of those creeps can put this stuff together we’ll have our movie out. A real movie... (he breaks off --) Silence... (or some- thing close to it)... From the FILM still run- ing on the big screen -- there comes a faint sighing of wind...

dialogues.speaker: THE RANCH
dialogues.text: Dawn -- very early, very grey... The last of the cars are pulling out of the drive- way and heading for home. The house itself would seem to be deserted. CALB (the general handy- man) is searching the empty, littered rooms, calling out an occasional “Mr. Hannaford -- “ as he goes... Silence answers him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn -- very early and very grey... The last of the cars pulls out of the driveway heading for home... The house itself would seem to be deserted. CALB (the general handyway) is searching the littered rooms, calling an occasional “Mister Hannaford” -- as he goes... Silence at first... Then a murmuring can be heard somewhere in the house.  205

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: --- Old friends are old, and that’s the trouble with ‘em...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This is, in fact, the continuation of some talk between JAKE and VOGEL, the start which we heard early last night, and which had been recorded. ) JAKE'S VOICE (contd. ) They don’t grow old -- it’s just something they stumble over and fall into. And they all seem so... surprised. Poor sods -- they look at you as though there was something you could do about it... CALB goes searching... through the house and out onto the terrace by the pool... But JAKE’S VOICE grows fainter... (But there is someone else here) ...

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVE-IN THEATRE
dialogues.text: Almost empty now...

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hey, Brooksie --  206

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: What happened to the critic lady?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She'll live --

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: She'll live to write about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fuck her.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Almost everybody’s gone, looks like... Zarah, too?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She left.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: (with just a whiff of JAKE in his tone) So she did, uncle, so she did... Maybe she don’t love us like she used to.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Maybe... Don’t let him get you down, Brooksie.  207

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not yet. Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: We’re hanging tough, Billy. -.. Let’s see if we can get a laugh out of him -- He turns and looks toward the place where JAKE is sitting along in the sports car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It plays for a time... Then we hear: JOHN DALE’S VOICE Morning, Hannaford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAKE'S car lurches to a stop... JOHN DALE'S figure -- unmistak- able in its raincoat and with the curly ash-blonde hair, is in the foreground... JAKE peers at him through the murky light...  208

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Johnny -- ? No answer. Came to my party after all -- JOHN DALE’S VOICE I came to get my car, Hannaford.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (after a silence) Get in. I’11 drive you... JOHN DALE’S VOICE No, thanks. Another silence...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Chicken -- ? There is no reply... After a long moment, JAKE turns away, puts his foot on the pedal and, with a frantic screeching of tires, the car swerves out through the gates and off down the highway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the voice of John Dale, but it was not John Dale. OTTERLAKE takes off the wig. (Much earlier we've seen him idly picking it from the head of one of the dummies)...  209

dialogues.speaker: OTTERLAKE
dialogues.text: I’m better than I think... And much less funny -- He tosses the wig to MAVIS, who utters a tiny whine of disgust upon receiving it. Ripping off the rain- coat which had completed his disguise, he climbs into his car. Come on, sweetie... The old man didn’t get to make it with you, did he, so who does that mean you’re going home with? According to the critic lady, with a virgin. He starts the car...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The real JOHN DALE...

dialogues.speaker: THE RANCH
dialogues.text: Moving through the empty house... The voice of the handyman be heard calling again: “Mr. Hannaford...” Silence at first. Then the murmuring from another room...  210

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: .-.. Remember those Berbers -- up in the Atlas? They wouldn't let us point a camera at ‘em. They’re certain that it... dries up something... Following the sound, JOHN DALE moves into --

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG ROOM
dialogues.text: Here, sprawled in a huge leather chair, HIGGAM is sleeping, his tape recorder on his lap... JAKE'S VOICE (CONT’D) The old eye, you know, behind the magic box. Could be it’s an evil eye, at that... Medusa’s...

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVE-IN THEATRE
dialogues.text: A deserted field, except for THE ACTRESS sitting alone in her little car... The wailing wind and the gypsy song on the theatre’s sound track are joined now by the wailing of police sirens -- heard very distantly... The sky is clear enough to show the hint of a black pillar of smoke somewhere far off...  211

dialogues.speaker: JAKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who knows, maybe you can stare too hard at something. Huh? -- Drain out the virtue -- suck out the living juice... ON THE SCREEN -— The moving images fade under the dead pallor of the rising day... THE ACTRESS starts up her car and drives away. JAKE'S VOICE (contd. ) You shoot the great places and the pretty people -- All those girls and boys... Shoot ‘em dead... The air is lightening; morning is almost here; the sun is just under the horizon, and JAKE’S FILM is very faint now on the big screen... THE GIRL seems like a ghost as she returns to the shapeless wreck which is all that’s left of the OLD MAN'S dwelling place. For a moment longer -- dim as the image itself -- there rises from somewhere beneath this ruin the gypsy lament... But already the wind ius blowing it away... Blowing everything away...  212 Layer after layer flies off into the sky... And ten, as the great dust cloud settles, there is nothing -- only a vast lunar emptiness... And silence... JAKE'S VOICE (contd. ) (on the sound track of the projected film) Cut. The image disappears from the screen. The movie is over.
